clues.text: Artemisia Gentileschi was paid 3 times the going rate to paint this ceiling painter's family home
This president became fascinated with artist Maria Cosway in Paris while serving as minister to France
Given government approval to cross-dress, Rosa Bonheur was the first woman given this French award
She learned the art of wax modeling from her uncle & served as art tutor at Versailles before moving to London
Paintings by Guillemine Benoist & other female artists were misidentified as by this French male neoclassicist
Nickname of I. Lewis Libby, who grew up to be VP Cheney's powerful chief of staff
This "grouchy" librettist won a 1950 Pulitzer for his work on "South Pacific"
The first player in the National League to be MVP 2 years in a row, he's known as "Mr. Cub"
22nd & 24th POTUS
This patron saint of Mediterranean sailors lent his name to a phenomenon seen during storms
Rotund Cosby-voiced cartoon character who penned works like "The Plague" & "The Stranger"
"Daniel" warbler whose "Essay Concerning Human Understanding" helped spur the Enlightenment
Current African-American Supreme Court Justice who enlightened his fellow Brits with a "Leviathan" of a book in 1651
Pirate flag that symbolizes a 13th c. English scholar who was jailed when his talk of science was deemed heretical
Not a "Bewitched" daughter, the MTV news reporter who wowed 'em in Denmark with the existential "Fear and Trembling"
Atomic number 20
Ointment of zinc & ferric oxide used for inflammations of the skin
From the Latin for "destruction", it's a state of deep distress or misfortune
Fabric named for a city in India
Ancient Roman name for the region of Scotland
The Houyhnhnm are a race of sentient equines than appear in Part IV of this title man's "Travels"
Barnum & Kip were a pair of horses in this author's "Little House" series
Rosco, belonging to John Grady Cole, is one of "All the" these in a novel by Cormac McCarthy
It has been surmised that this hard-working horse from "Animal Farm" got his name from a Chinese revolt
Vronsky sits incorrectly in Frou-Frou's saddle, causing the horse's death in this 1875 novel
As Shrek, this actor is told that his donkey talks, & says, "Yeah, it's getting him to shut up that's the trick"
Going where no man had gone before, as Ozzie in "Over the Hedge": "Playing possum is what we do.  We die so...we live"
He voiced Shaggy on the 1969-1972 TV series "Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!"
Tara Strong has voiced Timmy Turner of "The Fairly Oddparents" & babies up as this Nick TV show's Dil Pickles
Billy West voices (among others!) Prof. Farnsworth, Zapp Brannigan, Dr. Zoidberg, Fry & Richard Nixon on this Fox TV Show
Weigmann's "Der Klarinetten-Macher", about clarinet inventor Johann Denner, is one of these works
Pipe up if you know Bach wrote a "Little Book" of 45 Chorales for this instrument
Nissel, Brainin, Schidlof & Lovett performed as the "Amadeus" this type of group
At 18, this composer studied with Friedrich Wieck & met Wieck's 9-year-old daughter Clara, his future wife
The horn players took a break on Nov. 5, 1938 when the NBC Symphony premiered Barber's "Adagio for" these
Yom Kippur is Hebrew for "Day of" this
This fine powder is used to give color to such products as inks & paints
Mourn
Poe wrote, "Hear the sledges with the bells--silver bells! What a world of" this "their melody foretells"
The Bible says the angel at Jesus' tomb wore this, meaning garments, that was "white as snow"
Tennyson's "Ode On the Death of the Duke Of" this place was considered pretty beefy by some
This author's "The Awakening" finds Mme. Pontellier shaken by the appropriate strains of a Polish composer
These title islands in a Vonnegut parable are home to the doomed survivors of the cruise ship Bahia de Darwin
Hawthorne's "The Marble" this was inspired by a Praxiteles sculpture
Ornithological title name of a prison in a John Cheever novel
Susan Sarandon & Geena Davis discover "there's no such thing as justifiable robbery" in this film
Paul Giamatti delivers the line "Quaffable but uh...far from transcendent" in this 2004 film
Careful! You will say one word 4 times (not 5, not 3!) in the title of this zany 1963 road comedy
clues.response: It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World

clues.text: Hey man, hit the road with Wyatt & Billy, man & check out Phil Spector as Connection in this 1969 film, man
Say it! Say it! Say Julie Hagerty lost the nest egg in this 1985 Albert Brooks comedy
Leopold II succeeded his dad as King of the Belgians in this year that also marked the end of a war in the U.S.
You may have "Red" about his father, Erik, but he was so successful he was nicknamed "The Lucky"
This only son of Prince Andrew of Greece became a British subject in 1947 & gained a dukedom
On May 14, 1643 the Sun rose on the reign of this 4-year-old king whose father had died at age 42
The devil you say! He inherited the title "Duke of Normandy" from his dad Robert the Devil in 1035
The saliva of this species of flying mammal contains an anticoagulant
When not in use, it's retracted by a woodpecker, & it may wrap around under the skull, beneath the skin
The wisent is considered the European version of this animal once essential to the lives of the Plains Indians
This deep-sea fish takes it name from the fact that it dangles an enticing appendage over its mouth to attract prey
The ursus californicus variety of this fierce brown bear is featured on California's state seal

rounds.text: The area that the people of ancient Rome called this was their city's equivalent of the Greek agora
